The significance of the partisan guerilla movement can be assessed under three aspects!
First, psychological. The partisans restored self-confidence and self-respect to the
demoralized nation, which went through a kind of new Hisorgimento, or resurrection, and
sealed with here best citizens* blood her reaffirmation of human and liberal ideals.
Second, military. They gave a substantial contribution to the Allied victory in Italy
and to the general war effort by pinning down 12 of the 32 German and Fascist Republican
divisions, thus enabling the Allied armies to divert large forces to other operational
theaters and, finally, preventing the Germans from organising their last stand in the Alpine
redoubt.
Third, political. The partisan movement provided an inspired new' leadership to postwar
Italy. It exercised a decisive role in the repudiation of a Fascist-contaminated monarchy bjj
the Italian people; in the setting up of a democratic republic, and regaining for Italy a
respected place among the free nations of Europe.

HOVEYi This year's orientation included lectures on contemporary Italian music, art
and literature; one on the Italian press; and two on United States political and economic
polioy in Italy.
Extras included bus trips to nearby places of interest! Assisi, the city of St.
Francis; Siena, Orvieto, Areas®. Fulbrighters attended the famous sacred music festival,
held annually in Perugia.
Inevitably, the whole experience had its impact. Americans learned that one can sur¬
vive without a daily hot bath. They had to, because Perugia's old aqueduct was ailing and
the water supply was short. They soon forgot about peeling Italian grapes, and decided it
was safe to eat those wonderful Italian cheeses5 Bel Passe, Gorgonsolam Mozzarella.
Americana who hadn't walked for pleasure in years got the habit of taking the autumn air
along with Peruginians in early evening along the Corso, blocked off for that purpose. Some
of the Fulbrighters made great strides with the Italian language.
It was a good bet that most of the hundred-odd Americans would be sorry to have orienta¬
tion month at Perugia come to an end.
Some would have a genuine impact on the I+alian scene. One ex-Fulbrighter, Professor
Frank M. Snowden of Howard university in Washington, had recently returned to Italy to be
cultural attache at the United States embassy in Home.
Pianist Alao Manoinelli of Steubenville, Ohio, v/ho played a concert for fellow Ful¬
brighters and Paruginians during 1953 orientation, was soloist with Bone's Santa Cecilia
symphony orchestra this Ootober, after winning Italy's covoted Busoni prize.
Fulbright singers who also performed at Perugia lest year won high praise for their
work in Puccini's "Madame Butterfly" in the 1954 autumn opera season at Spoleto. Critics
called a Chicago soprano, Edith Lang, one of the season's discoveries.
A 24-year-old Pittsburgh conductor and 1952 Fulbrighter, Lorin Haazol, directed
Florence's Maggie Musicals orchestra in its first broadoast concert of the fall season.
